awd_titl_txt: Tools for Teaching and Learning Engineering Practices: Pathways Towards Productive Identity Work in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. Identifying with engineering is critical to help students pursue engineering careers. This project responds to this persistent large-scale problem. The I-Engineering framework and tools address both the learning problem (supporting students in learning engineering design) and the identity problem (supporting students in recognizing that they belong in engineering). I-Engineering will support identity development as a part of learning two core practices in engineering: 1) defining problems and 2) designing solutions. In particular, the I-Engineering framework and tools will help middle grades teachers and students engage in the engineering design process using meaningful, authentic and often youth-driven contexts. The project will ground this work in two engineering design challenges: 1) safe and green commutes and 2) portable energy, both of which exemplify engineering for sustainable communities. The objectives are to: 1) To develop research-based understandings of how to support identity development among middle school students from underrepresented backgrounds in the context of learning engineering. 2) To develop and refine a framework and tools (I-Engineering) in support of student learning and identity development in engineering with a focus on sustainability.  3) To collaborate with grades 6 and 7 teachers to implement and refine I-Engineering for classroom use. 4) To study whether the I-Engineering framework/tools support identity development in engineering among middle school students from underrepresented backgrounds. 

The project draws upon design-based implementation research to develop and test the I-Engineering framework and tools among students and teachers in grades 6 and 7. Using social practice theory, how aspects of the learning environment shape identity development will be identified, yielding information on the impact of the instructional tools generated. The research questions are grounded in two areas: supporting identity development in engineering, understanding how students progress in their engineering development and patterns across implementation of the I-Engineering resources. Studies will shed light on mechanisms that support identity development in engineering, how that might be scaffolded, and how such scaffolds can transport across context. The mixed-method student- and classroom-level studies will allow for empirical claims regarding how and under what conditions youth from underrepresented backgrounds may progress in their identity development in engineering. The research plan includes student case studies drawing on task-based interviews, observations and student work and classroom studies using observations, student and teacher interviews, an engineering identity survey, student work and formative assessments of engineering practices. I-Engineering will reach over 500 students and their teachers in schools that serve predominantly underrepresented populations. The project team will disseminate the findings, framework and tools in support of teaching engineering practices, and promoting understanding of the importance of identity development in broadening participation.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: I-Engineering addresses two pressing challenges faced by middle school youth from underrepresented backgrounds: 1) opportunities to learn engineering meaningfully, and to apply it to understanding and solving real world problems (?learning?), and 2) the desire/ability to see oneself as an important contributor to engineering (?identity?). To respond to these concerns, I-Engineering used participatory design approaches, in collaboration with teachers, community educators, youth, engineers and educational researchers, to produce:

  1. A framework for teaching Engineering for Sustainable Communities (EfSC) in the middle grades
  2. Tools and materials to support the implementation of the EfSC approach in middle grades classrooms, including:
    1. Engineering Design Challenges: 1) Electric Art; and 2) Sustainable Classrooms
    2. EfSC Planning Tools: Productive identity work in engineering design; Teaching engineering for sustainable communities; Community funds of knowledge in engineering; and Integrating community perspectives.
    3. EfSC Teaching Tools: Community Ethnography across the design cycle; Epistemic learning tools; Productive identity work; and Engineering design/practice tools.
    4. Curriculum Adaptation Tools: A teacher focused workbook for adapting relevant science and engineering units to the EfSC approach.
    5. A theory of change to guide studies of EfSC impacts on student learning and development. This theory of change centralizes the modes of student engagement needed to integrate the salience of youths? community-ties via community ethnography as pedagogy, and youths? engineering innovations as agentic responses. 

 

All tools and materials are downloadable from http://EngineerIam.org

 

Tools and materials were implemented in 37 classrooms in two school districts over 4 years (20 teachers and over 1000 students). Using classroom studies and student/teacher case studies, we developed a comprehensive data repository including: Student work, exit passes, student interviews, and observations, teacher interviews, teacher reflective notes and conversations and observations. Teachers and students participated as co-analyzers in several of our analyses.

 

Broader Impact: Key findings of classroom studies and learner case studies include:

 

Identity Work

EfSC creates opportunities for productive identity work through the creation of educative spaces for youth to authentically engage in engineering design. These spaces foster opportunities for youth to care about each other, their classroom and community, to use both their everyday ingenuity/funds of knowledge and developing STEM expertise to make a difference, and to co-own authentic designs. 

 

Community ethnography supports students in deeply engaging in the NGSS-outlined engineering practices of defining problems and designing solutions. To define practices, students ask questions and gather information to determine specific challenges that need to be addressed. In this process, they gather and analyze information to properly define the dimensions of a problem. While students engage in designing solutions, they determine and balance different constraints for their science and engineering design. Organizing learning engineering design around youths? everyday experiences and community wisdom through a community ethnography design approach shifts how students conceptualize engineering design from a school-based task to affecting real-world change. This conceptual shift increases student identity and agency to be able to say that ?I can solve this problem collaboratively right here in my community, right now, using what I know.?

 

Learning

Two I-Engineering epistemic toolsets: a) community engineering and ethnography tools for defining problems, and b) integrating perspectives in design specification and optimization through iterative design sketch‐up and prototyping?work to support the following: a) Students' recruitment of multiple epistemologies; b) Navigation of multiple epistemologies; and c) students' onto‐epistemological developments in engineering. The tools worked when they were taken up in particular ways by teacher and students, and how the nature of their iterative engagement with the tools led to outcomes in ways that were equitable and consequential, both to students' engineering experiences and their engineering onto‐epistemological developments, and also in responding to the community injustices prototypes were designed to address. 

 

An EfSC approach supports strong connections between classrooms and communities by fostering students? critical consciousness on engineering design and community sustainability concerns. When critical consciousness is viewed as integral to how and why learning STEM matters in everyday life and hoped-for futures (rather than separate), students excel in learning engineering design. Classroom discussions focused on sustainability, whose ideas matter, making a difference, and empathy, served as power launching pads for delving deeper into technical content, iterating projects, persisting through engineering challenges, and seeking opportunities to educate others about their engineering designs. 

 

Teacher Learning

Teachers? vision of justice-oriented engineering teaching can be expanded through their attunement to the social dimensions of engineering made visible through an EfSC approach. This attunement centered broader sociopolitical questions of what is right, what is just and what is good with respect to the engineering process, and what it meant to teach engineering.
